{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Avigdor Lieberman |image = Avigdor Lieberman - 2011.jpg |office = [[Foreign Affairs Minister of Israel|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] |primeminister = [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] |deputy = [[Danny Ayalon]] |term_start = 1 April 2009 |term_end = 18 December 2012 |predecessor = [[Tzipi Livni]] |successor = [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] |office1 = [[Strategic Affairs Minister of Israel|Minister of Strategic Affairs]] |primeminister1 = [[Ehud Olmert]] |term_start1 = 30 October 2006 |term_end1 = 18 January 2008 |predecessor1 = ''New office'' |successor1 = [[Ehud Olmert]] |office2 = [[Ministry of Transport, National Infrastructure and Road Safety|Minister of Transport, National Infrastructure and Road Safety]] |primeminister2 = [[Ariel Sharon]] |term_start2 = 28 February 2003 |term_end2 = 6 June 2004 |predecessor2 = [[Tzachi Hanegbi]] |successor2 = [[Meir Sheetrit]] |office3 = [[Energy and Water Resources Ministry|Minister of Energy and Water Resources]] |primeminister3 = [[Ariel Sharon]] |term_start3 = 13 March 2002 |term_end3 = 18 September 2003 |predecessor3 = [[Avraham Shochat]] |successor3 = [[Effi Eitam]] |office4 = Member of the [[Knesset]] |term_start4 = 1999 |term_end4 = 14 December 2012 |birth_name = Evet Lvovich Liberman |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1958|6|5|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Chi?in?u|Kishinev]], [[Soviet Union]]
(now Chi?in?u, [[Moldova]]) |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Yisrael Beiteinu]] |alma_mater = [[Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv|University of Kiev]]
[[Hebrew University of Jerusalem|Hebrew University]]
[[Agricultural State University of Moldova|Chi?in?u Agriculture Institute]] |allegiance = {{flag|Israel}} |branch = [[File:Flag of the Israel Defence Forces.svg|30px]] [[Israel Defense Forces]] |serviceyears = 1978–1980 |rank = [[File:IDF Ranks Rav turai.svg|50px]] [[Corporal]] |unit = [[File:Idf artillery corps.svg|30px]] [[Artillery Corps (Israel)|Artillery Corps]] }} '''Avigdor Lieberman''' ({{lang-he|??????? ??????}}, {{IPA-he|avi??dor ?liberman|IPA}}, {{Audio|Avigdor lieberman.ogg|(audio)}}; born '''Evet Lvovich Liberman''', {{lang-ru|????? ???????? ?????????}}, 5 June 1958){{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUSL9314428|title=FACTBOX – Israel's Avigdor Lieberman|accessdate=9 February 2009|date=9 February 2009|agency=Reuters|first=Alastair|last=MacDonald|archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20090212130746/http://www.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUSL9314428|archivedate=12 February 2009 |deadurl=no}} is a [[Moldavian SSR|Soviet]]-born [[Israeli Jews|Israeli]] politician. He was a member of the [[Knesset]], [[Foreign Affairs Minister of Israel|Israeli Minister of Foreign Affairs]] and [[Deputy leaders of Israel|Deputy Prime Minister of Israel]] until 18 December 2012, when his resignation, caused by an investigation in which he was charged with fraud and breach of trust, took effect.[http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4320345,00.html "Lieberman tenders resignation", ''Ynet News'', 16 December 2012] He is the founder and leader of the [[Yisrael Beiteinu]] party, whose electoral base are the immigrants from the former [[Soviet Union]].[http://www.politico.co.il/article.asp?rId=1465 How many seats did the Russians give Lieberman] Politico, 16 February 2009 {{he icon}} Following Lieberman's resignation, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu stepped in and as of late December 2012 is serving as acting Foreign Minister.http://www.haaretz.com/news/national/lieberman-aides-still-running-foreign-ministry-with-netanyahu-s-approval.premium-1.489969 Lieberman first entered the Knesset in 1999, and has since served in numerous roles in the [[Israeli government|government]], including as [[National Infrastructure Minister of Israel|Minister of National Infrastructure]], [[Transportation Minister of Israel|Minister of Transportation]], [[Strategic Affairs Minister of Israel|Minister of Strategic Affairs]], [[Deputy leaders of Israel#Deputy Prime Minister|Deputy Prime Minister]], and [[Foreign Affairs Minister of Israel|Foreign Affairs Minister]]. ==Biography== ===Early life and early career=== Lieberman was born on 5 June 1958 in [[Chi?in?u|Kishinev]], [[Soviet Union]] (now [[Chi?in?u]], [[Moldova]]). His father Lev (18 May 1921 – 2 July 2007) had served in the [[Red Army]] and spent seven years in a [[Siberian]] [[Gulag]] under [[Joseph Stalin]]'s rule,http://www.reuters.com/article/2009/02/09/idUSL9314428 where he met Evet's mother Esther (born 2 July 1924).{{Citation needed|date=January 2012}} His family had a strong Jewish identity, and he spoke only [[Yiddish]] upto the age of three.http://www.patheos.com/Resources/Additional-Resources/All-Is-Heaven-with-Avigdor-Lieberman?offset=1&max=1 After high school, Lieberman applied to study international law at [[Kiev University]], but was, according to an interview, [[Jewish quota|rejected for being Jewish]]. He then temporarily enrolled at the [[Agricultural State University of Moldova|Chi?in?u Agriculture Institute]] with a [[hydrology|hydrological]] [[land improvement]] major.[http://www.dorledor.info/magazin/index.php?mag_id=2&art_id=19&pg_no=11 Dor le Dor interview], in [[Russian language|Russian]] Lieberman and his family [[Aliyah|immigrated]] to [[Israel]] in 1978, and Lieberman changed his first name to 'Avigdor'. He initially considered living in a [[kibbutz]] before moving into [[Beersheba]]. He was conscripted into the [[Israel Defense Forces]] and served in the [[Artillery Corps (Israel)|Artillery Corps]],{{cite journal|journal=[[Bamahane]]|title=Five Questions/Five Answers|page=p. 5|issue=2984th Edition|date=3 April 2009}} attaining the [[Military rank|rank]] of [[Corporal]]. After his military service, he enrolled in the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]] and earned a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in international relations and political science.[http://www.todayszaman.com/tz-web/yazarDetay.do?haberno=166971 Avigdor Lieberman: a man to watch].''[[Today's Zaman]]''. Published 5 February 2009. During his studies he was active in the student group, "Kastel", associated with the [[Likud]]. Relations between Kastel and Arab student groups were tense and often deteriorated into violence. According to ''[[Maariv]]'', based on the testimony of a witness who was a student at the time, Lieberman participated in a few of the violent clashes. Lieberman said that he was involved in two. [[Jamal Zahalka]], an Arab Knesset member from [[Balad (political party)|Balad]] who was also a student at the time and active in Arab groups, claimed that he remembers Lieberman as yelling a lot but avoiding any of the rough action.{{cite news|url=http://www.nrg.co.il/online/1/ART1/865/489.html|title=Lieberman The Student|last=Leibowitz|first= Sarah|publisher=[[nrg Maariv]]|language=Hebrew|date=14 March 2009}} On the eve of the 2009 elections in Israel, ''[[Haaretz]]'' wrote that Lieberman was briefly involved with the [[Kach and Kahane Chai|Kach]] party of [[Rabbi Meir Kahane]] shortly after his immigration to Israel. The membership claims were based on the testimony of two activists in the movement, [[Avigdor Eskin]] and [[Yosef Dayan]], who said that Lieberman was a member of the party for a short-term period. Lieberman rejected the story, and called the publication an "orchestrated provocation".{{cite news|title=Lieberman was involved in radical right Kach movement|first=Lily|last=Galili|work=[[Haaretz]]|date=5 February 2009|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1061350.html}}{{cite web|url=http://www.inn.co.il/News/News.aspx/185129|title=Account: Lieberman was a Member of the Kach Movement|last=Tena|first=Samuel|date=4 February 2009|publisher=Arutz Sheva|accessdate=29 March 2009|archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20090412025306/http://inn.co.il/News/News.aspx/185129|archivedate=12 April 2009|deadurl=no}}{{he icon}} Kach was barred from participating in the [[Israeli legislative election, 1988|election]] in 1988 under the revised [[Knesset Elections Law]] banning parties that incited racism and was declared a terrorist organization in 1994.[http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/Government/Law/Legal%20Issues%20and%20Rulings/THE%20KACH%20MOVEMENT%20-%20BACKGROUND%20-%94 March 2003 The Kach Movement – Background] Israel Ministry of Foreign Affairs, 3 March 1994{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/antiarab-kach-group-outlawed-in-israel-belated-response-to-hebron-massacre-is-likely-to-help-get-peace-negotiations-going-again-1428983.html|title= Anti-Arab Kach group outlawed in Israel: Belated response to Hebron massacre is likely to help get peace negotiations going again|last=Richards|first=Charles|date=14 March 1994|work=The Independent|location=London|accessdate=1 April 2009}} While studying at the Hebrew University, Lieberman was busy job hunting and was given work by [[Tzahi Hanegbi]], then a student chairman at the university, as a [[bouncer (doorman)|bouncer]][http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article5679395.ece Ex-bouncer Avigdor Lieberman muscles his way into Israeli politics] in the student club "Shablul" (lit. snail) where he met his future wife. A year later, Lieberman was promoted to a general manager, responsible for all the activities at the club.[http://www.nrg.co.il/online/1/ART1/865/489.html Lieberman The Student] Ma'ariv {{he icon}} From 1983 to 1988, Lieberman helped found the ''Zionist Forum for Soviet Jewry'', and was a member of the ''Board of the Jerusalem Economic Corporation'' and the Secretary of the [[Jerusalem]] branch of the ''Histadrut Ovdim Le'umit'' ("National Workers' Union"). In 1988, he started working with [[Benjamin Netanyahu]]. From 1993 to 1996, following Netanyahu's election as party leader, Lieberman served as Director-General of the Likud party. After Netanyahu was elected [[Prime Minister of Israel|Prime Minister]], Lieberman served as Director-General of the [[Office of the Prime Minister (Israel)|Prime Minister's Office]] from 1996 to 1997. ===Later career=== In 1997, Lieberman resigned from Likud after Prime Minister Netanyahu granted concessions to the Palestinians in the [[Wye River Memorandum]], and expressed disappointment when [[Yisrael BaAliyah]], a new immigrant's party headed by [[Natan Sharansky]] that had right-center leanings, did not quit the coalition government in protest. In 1999, Lieberman formed the [[Yisrael Beiteinu]] party to create a platform for Soviet immigrants who supported a hard line in negotiations with the Palestinians. The party ran for the [[Knesset]] during the [[Israeli legislative election, 1999|1999 legislative election]], and ran on a joint list with [[Aliyah (political party)|Aliyah]], a party formed by [[Michael Nudelman]] and [[Yuri Stern]], who had broke away from Yisrael BaAliyah. The new party won four seats, one of which was taken by Lieberman. Lieberman served on the [[Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee]] and State Control Committee, and as Chairman of the Israel-Moldova Parliamentary Friendship League.[http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/Government/Personalities/From+A-Z/Avigdor+Lieberman.htm Avigdor Lieberman] Israel Ministry of Foreign Affairs In March 2001, Lieberman was appointed [[National Infrastructure Minister of Israel|Minister of National Infrastructure]], but resigned the post in March 2002. In the [[Israeli legislative election, 2003|2003 legislative election]], Yisrael Beiteinu ran on a joint list with the [[National Union (Israel)|National Union]]. The joint list won seven seats, with Yisrael Beiteinu being alloted four of them. In February 2003, Lieberman was appointed [[Transportation Minister of Israel|Minister of Transport]], and chose to resign from the Knesset to take a seat in the Cabinet. He maintained leadership of the party and returned to the Knesset in 2006—later, he would simultaneously serve in the Knesset and Cabinet. In May 2004, Lieberman was dismissed from the [[Cabinet of Israel|cabinet]] by Prime Minister [[Ariel Sharon]] due to his opposition to the [[Israel's unilateral disengagement plan|Gaza disengagement]],[http://www.nytimes.com/2004/06/04/world/sharon-is-expected-to-fire-2-from-cabinet-before-gaza-vote.html Sharon Is Expected to Fire 2 From Cabinet Before Gaza Vote] New York Times, 4 June 2004 and Yisrael Beiteinu left the government in June in protest of the disengagement. [[Image:2007 10 15 israel1 600.jpg|200px|thumb|Lieberman and then-[[United States Secretary of State]] [[Condoleezza Rice]] in 2007]] In the [[Israeli legislative election, 2006|2006 legislative election]], Lieberman's party split from the National Union to run alone. The party won eleven seats, a gain from its previous six seats. It was initially in the opposition, but after a few months, in October 2006, Lieberman and [[Prime Minister of Israel|Prime Minister]] [[Ehud Olmert]] signed a coalition agreement under which Lieberman became the [[Deputy leaders of Israel#Deputy Prime Minister|Deputy Prime Minister]] and [[Strategic Affairs Minister of Israel|Minister of Strategic Affairs]], a newly created position with a focus towards the [[Iran and weapons of mass destruction|strategic threat from Iran]]. In December 2006, he called Iranian [[nuclear proliferation]] "the biggest threat facing the Jewish people since the Second World War." He advocated that Israel join the [[European Union]] and [[NATO]].[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1167467851423&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull Lieberman pushes Israel to join EU|Israel|Jerusalem Post] Lieberman resigned his cabinet position and [[Yisrael Beiteinu]] left the coalition in January 2008; he cited his opposition to the resuming peace talks, saying that "Negotiations on the basis of [[land for peace]] are a critical mistake ... and will destroy us."[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/mar/16/avigdor-lieberman-israel Hardliner Avigdor Lieberman set to become Israel's foreign minister]. By Rory McCarthy. ''[[The Guardian]]''. Published 16 March 2009. Yisrael Beiteinu, which was described at times as Lieberman's "one man's party" for its media-closed meetings and party members' reluctance to give interviews,[http://reshet.ynet.co.il/?????/News/programs/MainNewscast/Article,13394.aspx Introducing: the New Face of Yisrael Beiteinu] Israel News 2 {{he icon}} emerged as the third largest party in Israel after [[2009 Israeli elections|2009 legislative election]] and on 16 March, it entered into the coalition government led by Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]]. Lieberman was appointed [[Foreign Affairs Minister of Israel|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] and [[Deputy Prime Minister]]. On 25 October 2012, Lieberman and Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] announced that their respective political parties, [[Likud]] and [[Yisrael Beiteinu]], had merged and would run together on a single ballot in Israel's 22 January 2013 general elections. “In view of the challenges we’re facing, we need responsibility on a national level ... We’re providing a true alternative, and an opportunity for the citizens to stabilize leadership and government.,” Lieberman said.{{cite web|last=Leshem|first=Elie|title=Netanyahu, Liberman announce they’ll run joint list for Knesset|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/netanyahu-announces-merger-with-israel-beytenu-promises-to-lead-with-strength/|publisher=The Times of Israel|accessdate=27 October 2012}} ===Term as Minister of Foreign Affairs=== {{Infobox member of the Knesset | image= | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1958|6|5|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Chi?in?u|Kishinev]], [[Moldavian Soviet Socialist Republic|Moldavian SSR]], [[Soviet Union]] | Year of Aliyah = 1978 | death_date = | Knesset(s) = [[Israeli legislative election, 1999|15]], [[Israeli legislative election, 2003|16]], [[Israeli legislative election, 2006|17]], [[Israeli legislative election, 2009|18]] | Party = [[Yisrael Beiteinu]] | Former parties = [[Likud]] | Gov't roles = '''[[Deputy leaders of Israel#Deputy Prime Minister|Deputy Prime Minister]]'''
'''[[Foreign Affairs Minister of Israel|Minister of Foreign Affairs]]'''
[[Strategic Affairs Minister of Israel|Minister of Strategic Affairs]]
[[Transportation Minister of Israel|Minister of Transportation]]
[[National Infrastructure Minister of Israel|Minister of National Infrastructure]] }} Upon taking office as the [[Minister of Foreign Affairs]], Lieberman posed a clear message against application of provisions discussed at the [[Annapolis Conference]], which stipulated the settlement of all negotiated issues prior to their implementation in the field, adding that these discussions were never [[ratified]] by the [[Knesset]]. He noted that Israel must abide, nonetheless, by the ''[[road map for peace]]'' – which held a demand for an 'End of Palestinian violence' as a first phase for furtherance of the negotiations process—as well as by the two accompanying [[George Tenet|Tenet]] and [[Anthony Zinni|Zinni]] documents.[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1238562881455&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull Lieberman: Annapolis doesn't obligate us]. ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]''. Published 1 April 2009. Lieberman had previously opposed the ''[[road map for peace|road map]]'' at the time of its adoption.[http://www.danielpipes.org/6258/avigdor-liebermans-brilliant-debut Avigdor Lieberman's Brilliant Debut]. By [[Daniel Pipes]]. [[FrontPageMagazine.com]] Published 2 April 2009. He left [[Ehud Olmert]]'s government due to his opposition to the [[Annapolis Conference]].[http://www.news1.co.il/Archive/001-D-195928-00.html?tag=19-25-06 Annapolis has no binding validity], news1, 1 April 2009. Lieberman followed his 1 April message with concerns that "[others] stand over us with a stopwatch" and that responsible and serious formulations of policy will take between one and two months.[http://thebulletin.us/articles/2009/04/09/top_stories/bullet_points/doc49ddb9a981973320206239.txt Israeli FM: Don't Stand Over Us With A Stopwatch]. By David Bedein. ''[http://thebulletin.us/ The Bulletin]''. Published 9 April 2009. Lieberman's office stated in early April that peace talks will continue when Palestinian government officials crack down on attacks against Israelis, after which the Israeli administration will reciprocate by freezing [[Israeli settlement|settlement construction or expansion in the West Bank]]. That position contradicts the [[Obama administration]]'s new approach to the peace efforts, where Israel is requested to freeze all construction, including "natural growth" (i.e. "within existing construction lines"){{cite web|url=http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1245924934512&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull|title=Lieberman slams Obama's Iran policy|date=26 June 2009|work=The Jerusalem Post|accessdate=12 July 2009}} regardless of Palestinian commitments. The office also told U.S. [[special envoy]] [[George J. Mitchell|George Mitchell]] that past negotiations did not bring any real results. Lieberman himself said in April, "The situation is deadlocked, and it is not because of us".[http://www.miamiherald.com/news/world/story/994845.html Top Israeli diplomat: Don't rush us back to peace talks]. ''[[The Miami Herald]]''. Published 11 April 2009. He argued that a stable, successful peace effort requires Americans to focus on preventing Iran from developing a nuclear weapon.[http://www.mcclatchydc.com/251/story/66360.html Plan for Palestinian state is 'dead end,' Israel tells U.S.] ''[[McClatchy Newspapers]]''. Published 16 April 2009. Lieberman and Prime Minister Netanyahu both planned to broaden the PR campaign overseen by the Foreign Ministry about Iran. Part of its new campaign focuses on Tehran's abuse of human rights and sponsorship of terrorism and also aims to appeal to those, such as the gay and lesbian communities, less concerned with Iran's nuclear aspirations and more fearful of its human rights abuses and mistreatment of minorities.{{cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1079589.html|title=Israel recruits gay community in PR campaign against Iran|author=Barak Ravid|work=[[Haaretz]]|date=20 April 2009}} Despite his status within the government, the Israeli police have questioned Lieberman three times from he took office to 11 April about the [[Avigdor Lieberman#Corruption investigations|ongoing corruption investigation]]. In early May 2009, Lieberman went on a European diplomatic mission, which went through Rome, Paris, Prague, and other cities. He met with his Foreign Minister counterparts, such as [[Frank-Walter Steinmeier]] of Germany, and he also paid his respects at [[Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe|Berlin's Holocaust memorial]], laying a wreath at the 19,000-square-meter monument. In 4 May 2009, in a press conference in [[Italy]], Avigdor Lieberman skirted around the issue of a [[Palestinian state]], stating that "This government's goal is not produce slogans or make pompous declarations, but to reach concrete results," adding that the government was still in the process of formulating its foreign policy.{{cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.co.il/hasite/spages/1082947.html|title=Foreign Minister, Avigdor Lieberman: We are committed to the Peace Process|language=Hebrew|work=Haaretz|accessdate=8 May 2009| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20090507153405/http://www.haaretz.co.il/hasite/spages/1082947.html| archivedate= 7 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} On another occasion in his trip, he stated that "Nothing is going to come out of this 'Peace Industry' except for conferences in five star Hotels and a waste of money".{{cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1083927.html|title=Lieberman: Nothing is going to come out of this 'Peace Industry' except for a waste of money|work=Haaretz|date=6 May 2009|accessdate=8 May 2009|archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20090511001317/http://haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1083927.html|archivedate=11 May 2009 |deadurl= no}} Generally speaking, the diplomatic mission was private and subject to restricted news coverage. On 7 May, ''[[Yediot Ahronot]]'' stated that Lieberman was appointed the minister in charge of strategic dialogue with the U.S.{{cite news|first=Roni|last=Sofer|url=http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-3712499,00.html|title=Lieberman will be responsible for the strategic dialogue with the U.S.|publisher=[[Yediot Ahronot]]|language=Hebrew|date=7 May 2009|accessdate=13 May 2009|archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20090510231750/http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-3712499,00.html|archivedate=10 May 2009|deadurl= no}} On 17 June, he appeared in a joint [[press conference]] with [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] in his first official visit to the U.S. Lieberman clashed with Clinton over the issue of [[Israeli settlements]], with Lieberman dismissing her call to end settlement expansion. ''[[Financial Times]]'' described the meeting as "one of the most tense encounters between the sides for several years".{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/614c98a4-5b98-11de-be3f-00144feabdc0,Authorised=false.html?_i_location=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fcms%2Fs%2F0%2F614c98a4-5b98-11de-be3f-00144feabdc0.html%3Fnclick_check%3D1&_i_referer=http%3A%2F%2Fhotair.com%2Farchives%2F2009%2F06%2F18%2Fhillary-demands-settlement-closure-but-not-freedom-in-iran%2F&nclick_check=1|work=Financial Times|accessdate=18 June 2009|date=18 June 2009|first=Daniel|last=Dombey|title=Clinton clashes with Israelis over settlers}} Clinton also rejected Lieberman's assertion that the [[George W. Bush administration|Bush administration]] had agreed to further building in the [[West Bank]]. [[Israel National News]] stated afterward that Lieberman and Prime Minister Netanyahu both have the same position of settlement expansion and for retaining [[Jerusalem]] as the [[Positions on Jerusalem|undivided capital of Israel]].{{cite news|publisher=[[Arutz Sheva]]|accessdate=18 June 2009|date=18 June 2009|title=Clinton vs. Lieberman in Bare Knuckles Fight over Yesha|author=Tzvi Ben Gedalyahu|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/131937| archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20090619161220/http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/131937|archivedate=19 June 2009 |deadurl= no}} In September 2009, Lieberman toured [[Africa]] to meet leaders and donate humanitarian aid, along with businessmen and officials from the Foreign Ministry, Finance Ministry, Defense Ministry, and National Security Council in an attempt to strengthen economic and trade ties and discuss the issue of the Iranian nuclear program.http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3770687,00.html As part of his policy to create more diplomatic openings for Israel, Lieberman also sought to strengthen ties with countries in Eastern and Central Europe. In a 2011 interview, Prime Minister Netanyahu said that Lieberman had opened important places where Israel had never really had diplomatic opening to before.[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v5t6A9wSMWo A World View Interview with Benjamin Netanyahu] ===Personal life=== [[Image:Nokdim.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Nokdim as photographed from the air in early 2006.]] Lieberman and his wife Ella ([[née]] Tzipkin, born 16 June 1959), also a Moldovan immigrant to Israel, have a daughter Michal (born 22 June 1983) and two sons, Yaakov (born 15 March 1988) and Amos (born 14 September 1990). They live in the [[Israeli settlement]] of [[Nokdim]], located in the [[Judean Desert]] of the [[West Bank]], where they have resided since 1988. Lieberman stated that, despite having lived there for so long, he is willing to leave his home as part of a peace agreement. He speaks [[Russian language|Russian]], [[Romanian language|Romanian]], [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] and [[English language|English]]. ==Political positions== ===Lieberman Plan=== {{Main|Lieberman Plan}} According to Lieberman, "The peace process is based on three false basic assumptions; that Israeli-Palestinian conflict is the main cause of instability in the Middle East, that the conflict is territorial and not ideological, and that the establishment of a Palestinian state based on the [[1967 borders]] will end the conflict."[http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3338320,00.html Lieberman: The unfaithful cannot be citizens] Ynetnews, 10 December 2006. In late May 2004, Lieberman proposed a plan in which the populations and territories of Israeli [[Jew]]s and [[Arab]]s, including some [[Israeli Arab]]s, would be "separated." According to the plan, also known as the "Populated-Area Exchange Plan," Israeli Arab towns adjacent to [[Palestinian Authority]] areas would be transferred to Palestinian Authority, and only those Arab Israelis who migrated from the area to within Israel's new borders and pledged loyalty to Israel would be allowed to remain Israeli citizens. On 30 May 2004, Prime Minister [[Ariel Sharon]] condemned Lieberman's statements, stating "We regard [[Israeli Arabs]] as part of the State of Israel."[http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/pages/ShArt.jhtml?itemNo=433141 Lieberman presents to Russia plan to expel 'disloyal' Arabs] [[Haaretz|Ha'aretz]], 30 May 2004. On 4 June 2004, as the disputes over the up-coming [[disengagement plan]] grew more intense, Sharon dismissed Lieberman from the cabinet.[http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/pages/ShArt.jhtml?itemNo=435378 PM sacks National Union ministers], [[Haaretz|Ha'aretz]], 5 June 2004.[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2004/jun/05/israel Sharon sacks hardliners who stand in his way] [[The Guardian]], 5 June 2004 After the [[2009 Israeli elections]], Lieberman said he changed his mind in recent years and decided to support the creation of a [[Palestinian state]]. He wrote in a letter to ''[[The Jewish Week]]'' that he "advocates the creation of a viable Palestinian state," and told ''[[The Washington Post]]'' that he would agree to the evacuation of [[Nokdim]] "if there really will be a two-state solution". He explained in the Knesset that "reality changes" and that his shift had occurred over the last few years.{{Cite news | last = Hoffman | first = Gil | title = Lieberman 'changes mind' on PA state | work=The Jerusalem Post | accessdate =4 March 2009 | date = 3 March 2009 | url = http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1236103147718&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull }} In his ''The Jewish Week'' article, Lieberman tried to explain his party's "no loyalty – no citizenship" campaign by writing: "During [[Operation Cast Lead]] in Gaza, I was appalled by the calls for the destruction of the State of Israel and for renewed suicide bombings that some Israeli Arab leaders called for at pro-Hamas rallies. Although 'responsible citizenship' had always been part of our platform, I realized that this was a burning issue that had to take top priority."{{Cite news | last = Benhorin | first = Yitzhak | title = Lieberman: I back creation of Palestinian state | work=Ynetnews | accessdate =4 March 2009 | date = 26 February 2009 | url = http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3678374,00.html | archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20090302063603/http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3678374,00.html| archivedate= 2 March 2009 | deadurl= no}} He explained his "responsible citizenship" platform and compared his position to the express policy of nations around the world, saying: "In the U.S., those requesting a [[Permanent residence (United States)|Green Card]] must take an oath that they will fulfill the rights and duties of citizenship.".{{Cite news | title = Lieberman: I support creation of viable Palestinian state | work=Haaretz | accessdate =4 March 2009 | date = 27 February 2009 | url = http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1067299.html | archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20090301130845/http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1067299.html| archivedate= 1 March 2009 | deadurl= no}} ===Other issues=== Lieberman supports Israeli membership in the [[European Union]] and [[NATO]].[http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/808111.html Avigdor Lieberman: Israel should press to join NATO, EU], [[Haaretz|Ha'aretz]], 1 January 2007. He considers [[Iran]] a serious threat to Israel, but initially came out in favor of further [[Sanctions against Iran|political/economic sanctions]] and opposed a military strike, saying that he cannot imagine the implications of armed action.{{Cite news | last = Mozgovaya | first = Natasha | title = Lieberman: I'm ready to quit my settlement home for peace | work=[[Haaretz]] | accessdate =11 April 2009 | date = 1 March 2009 | url = http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1067545.html | archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20090418075729/http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1067545.html| archivedate= 18 April 2009 | deadurl= no}} However, ''[[Haaretz]]'' later reported that Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] and Defense Minister [[Ehud Barak]] persuaded Lieberman to switch sides and support an attack.http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/netanyahu-trying-to-persuade-cabinet-to-support-attack-on-iran-1.393214 While his party is sometimes described as [[secularism|doctrinally secular]] and aiming to reduce the role of the [[Religion in Israel#Secular–religious status quo|rabbinical system in government]] by the [[news media]],{{Cite news | last = Prusher | first = Ilene R. | title = Key to who will govern Israel: Avigdor Lieberman | work=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] | accessdate =11 April 2009 | date = 12 February 2009 | url = http://www.csmonitor.com/2009/0212/p01s04-wome.html | archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20090308020042/http://www.csmonitor.com/2009/0212/p01s04-wome.html| archivedate= 8 March 2009 | deadurl= no}} it actually supports the continuation of the role of [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox]] [[Rabbinical Judaism|rabbinical courts]], but wants more nationally minded religious people, rather than the [[ultra-orthodox]], in charge. It does not advocate introducing [[Marriage in Israel|civil marriage within Israeli law]], but rather to find a solution to some of those who cannot marry under such laws. It does not advocate a [[separation of church and state|separation of religion and state]] in Israeli society.{{cite web|url=http://beytenu.org.il/85/2649/article.html|title=Party Platform on State and Religion|language=Hebrew|publisher=[[Yisrael Beiteinu]]|date=1 January 2009|accessdate=12 April 2009|archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20090418012447/http://beytenu.org.il/85/2649/article.html|archivedate=18 April 2009 |deadurl= no}} ==Mass media perception== A large number of [[mass media]] sources within and outside of Israel have labelled [[Yisrael Beiteinu]] and Lieberman as [[far right]]{{cite news|author=By ARON HELLER, Associated Press Writer news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/1533343/Jews-and-Arabs-can-never-live-together%2C-says-Israel%27s-vice-PM.html|title=Jews and Arabs can never live together, says Israel's However, in general, Israelis are divided on how to characterize Lieberman's politics.[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1233304740316&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull 'Lieberman isn't racist, Hamas is'|Elections 2009|Jerusalem Post]{{cite web|url=http://news.haaretz.co.il/hasen/pages/ShArtStEngPE.jhtml?itemNo=830503&contrassID=2&subContrassID=5&title=%27Not%20racist,%20stigmatized%20%27&dyn_server=172.20.5.5 |title=27Not%20racist,%20stigmatized%20%2|work=Haaretz|date=24 December 2006|accessdate=25 April 2010}}[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull&cid=1233304768730 Is Avigdor Lieberman a racist? No, but...|Elections 2009|Jerusalem Post] Yisrael Beiteinu has shown support for a [[two-state solution]] and were also noted for a [[secularism|secularist]] approach upon leading new legislation for civil marriage in Israel as well as pushing for some relaxation in the [[giyur|conversion]] process. Several commentators, however, noted that these positions do not coincide with the party's platform.{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1063791.html|title=A new Jewish state|work=Haaretz |accessdate=25 April 2010}}{{cite web|author=Aaron Sebag |url=http://www.neurope.eu/articles/92663.php |title=Israel's transition to new leadership – New Europe|publisher=Neurope.eu|accessdate=25 April 2010}}{{cite web|author=Philippa Runner|url=http://euobserver.com/24/27596|title=EUobserver / EU urges Israel to stick to peace process|work=EUobserver|accessdate=25 April 2010}} These positions which are contradictory to the tradition of [[Israeli right-wing politics|right wing politics in Israel]][[Francisco Gil-White]][http://www.hirhome.com/israel/left_right2.htm On the Orwellian use of the terms ‘left’ and ‘right,’ and on the dangers therein to Israeli politics], ''Historical and Investigative Research'', 12 April 2006. had been explained by [[Gershom Gorenberg]] as that following the [[Six Day War]], opinions were split regarding the occupied territory, where being right-wing meant a position of holding onto the territory while being left-wing addressed a high level of willingness to give that territory away. He notes Lieberman to not be a right-winger by those terms as he's talking about giving occupied lands as well as land from sovereign Israel."[http://www.theatlantic.com/doc/200704u/avigdor-lieberman Israel Is Our Home]", by Jennie Rothenberg Gritz, ''[[The Atlantic]]'', 14 March 2007. ==Controversies== ===Statements towards Arab members of Knesset=== A polarizing figure within Israeli politics, Lieberman is quoted as saying, "I've always been controversial because I offer new ideas. For me to be controversial, I think this is positive."{{cite news|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9805E2D71631F934A35751C1A9609C8B63 |title = Israeli Official Discusses Iran And His Controversial Agenda |date= 7 December 2006|work=The New York Times |last= Myre |first = Greg}} Lieberman has called to redraw the border between Israel and the [[West Bank]] so that Israel would include large Jewish settlement blocs and the Palestinian state would include large Arab-Israeli population centers. He proposed that Israel's citizens should sign a [[loyalty oath]] or [[Disenfranchisement#In_Israel|lose their]] [[right to vote]]. In November 2006, Lieberman, who described [[Arab members of the Knesset]] that meet with [[Hamas]] as "terror collaborators", called for their execution: "[[World War II]] ended with the [[Nuremberg Trials]]. The heads of the Nazi regime, along with their collaborators, were executed. I hope this will be the fate of the collaborators in [the Knesset]."[http://www.jpost.com/Home/Article.aspx?id=20821 Lieberman calls Arab MKs who meet with Hamas 'collaborators'] [[The Jerusalem Post]], Published 4 May 2006 The comment was attacked as racist by Eitan Cabel, a Labor party representative, and [[Ahmad Tibi]], leader of the Arab party [[Ta'al]] and one-time advisor to [[Yasser Arafat]], who demanded that, "a criminal investigation be initiated against Lieberman for violating the [[hate speech|law against incitement and racism]]".[http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3323027,00.html Prosecution: Lieberman's anti-Arab remarks kosher] [[Yedioth Ahronoth|Ynetnews]], 2 November 2006 Tibi strongly objected to Lieberman's ministerial appointment, describing him as "a [[racism|racist]] and a [[fascism|fascist]]". [[Labor Party (Israel)|Labour]] minister [[Ophir Pines-Paz]], who resigned over Lieberman's appointment, echoed Tibi's remarks, saying that Lieberman was tainted "by racist declarations and declarations that harm the democratic character of Israel".[http://news.independent.co.uk/world/middle_east/article1943313.ece Labour minister quits over Lieberman's role] [[The Independent]], 31 October 2006 In remarks in the [[Knesset]] in March 2008, shortly after the 6 March [[Mercaz HaRav massacre|attack]] at Jerusalem's [[Mercaz HaRav]] yeshiva, Lieberman commented that "yesterday's attack can not be disconnected from the Arab MKs incitement, which we hear daily in the Knesset."Haaretz Service:Lieberman: Jerusalem attack is product of Arab MK incitement [http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/961964.html] Directing his comments at Arab MKs whose comments Lieberman describes as [[anti-Israel]] incitement, he added that "a new administration will be established and then we will take care of you."{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/962767.html|title=Shahar Ilan: Lieberman to Arab MKs: One day we will 'take care of you'|work=Haaretz|location=Israel|accessdate=25 April 2010}} ===Statements about Egypt=== In 1998, news reports stated that Lieberman suggested the bombing of the [[Aswan Dam]] in retaliation for Egyptian support for [[Yasser Arafat]].[http://imeu.net/news/article0014364.shtml Avigdor Lieberman]. [[Institute for Middle East Understanding]]. Published 29 September 2008.[http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/1f80fa76-1293-11de-b816-0000779fd2ac,dwp_uuid=4d51ac52-ee0d-11dd-b791-0000779fd2ac.html Arab alarm over role for Lieberman]. By Andrew England, Heba Saleh, and Tobias Buck. ''[[Financial Times]]''. Published 17 March 2009. In 2001, reports stated that he told a group of ambassadors from the Former Soviet Union that if Egypt and Israel were ever to face off militarily again, that Israel could bomb the [[Aswan Dam]].[http://www.forward.com/articles/104068/ Washington Braces To Greet Lieberman as Foreign Minister]. By Nathan Guttman. ''[[The Forward]]''. Published 18 March 2009.[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/israel/5032256/Egypt-threatens-to-ignore-new-Israeli-foreign-minister.html Egypt threatens to ignore new Israeli foreign minister]. By Dina Kraft. ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''. Published 22 March 2009. Since the signing of the [[Egyptian–Israeli Peace Treaty]], which followed Egyptian President [[Anwar Sadat]]'s historic visit to Israel, multiple Israeli heads of state have visited Egypt on numerous occasions. However, Sadat's successor, [[Hosni Mubarak]], visited Israel only once—for [[Yitzhak Rabin]]'s funeral in 1995{{cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/news/home.aspx?fid=2&did=1000169390|title=????? ???? ??????: ??"? ?????? ????? ?? ????? ?????? ?????? – ?????|publisher=Globes|accessdate=25 April 2010}}—since he assumed the Presidency in 14 October 1981 and has never participated in talks on Israeli soil. In 2008, while on the [[Knesset]] speaker's podium during its memorial for [[Rehavam Ze'evi]], Lieberman raised the issue and said, "Mubarak never agreed to come here as president. He wants to talk to us? Let him come here. He doesn't want to talk to us? He can go to hell." Prime Minister [[Ehud Olmert]] and President [[Shimon Peres]] immediately apologized to the Egyptians. Lieberman accused the two of them of acting like "a battered wife". He explained his belief that the President and Prime Minister were wrong to ask forgiveness from Mubarak in that Egypt had provoked Israel just days earlier by identifying Israel as the enemy in a massive military exercise and that caricatures in the Egyptian media are akin to [[Nazi]] propaganda.{{cite news|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3616101,00.html|title=Lieberman: Israel acting like battered wife with Egypt|date=11 January 2008|publisher=[[YNET]]|accessdate=12 April 2009}} After Netanyahu began his term as Prime Minister in March 2009, government aides met with Egyptian officials and told them that Lieberman's role should not be a reason for tension between the two countries. News reports had previously been issued claiming that Egypt would not work with the Netanyahu administration unless Lieberman personally apologized.[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1238562926490&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull Mubarak invites Netanyahu for talks]. ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]''. Published 7 April 2009. The administration labeled them "inaccurate and out of all proportion".[http://www.turkishweekly.net/news/67850/-no-egyptian-ultimatum-on-lieberman-.html 'no Egyptian Ultimatum On Lieberman']. ''[[Turkish Weekly]]''. Published 22 March 2009. On 9 April, Mubarak invited Netanyahu to meet with him personally in [[Sharm e-Sheikh]]. Unofficial channels for discussion are also reportedly being considered.[http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1080907.html Egypt MP: Lieberman not welcome in Cairo unless he apologizes]. ''Haaretz''. During a meeting with Egyptian intelligence chief [[Omar Suleiman]] in April 2009, Lieberman made an attempt at an apology, expressing “his respect and appreciation for Egypt's leading role in the region and his personal respect for Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and Minister Suleiman".{{cite news|title=Egypt mending fences with Lieberman|url=http://www.icej.org/article/egypt_mending_fences_with_lieberman|accessdate=24 June 2010|newspaper=ICEJ News|date=23 April 2009}} On 21 August, Lieberman said that it is important for Israel to make sure that the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty is upheld, and not to remain silent as Egyptian military forces enter the Sinai. Concern was raised by Israeli officials over Egyptian failure to notify Israel about the deployment of tanks in the Sinai, which violates the peace treaty. Lieberman said, "We must make sure that every detail is upheld, otherwise we'll find ourselves in a slippery slope as far as the peace treaty is concerned."{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4271499,00.html|title=Lieberman: Don't let Egypt get away with violations|publisher=Yedioth Ahronot|date=21 August 2012| accessdate=21 August 2012|author=Somfalvi, Attila}} As instability in the Sinai continued into the next month, Lieberman responded to calls to deploy more troops with "The problem in Sinai is not the size of the forces, it is their readiness to fight, to put pressure and to carry out the job as is needed".[http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/israel-fm-egypt-peace-deal-17300638 "Israel FM Says No Changes to Egypt Peace Deal."] ABC News, 23 September 2012. On 28 August, Lieberman invited Egyptian President Morsi to visit Israel, after being encouraged by Morsi'is statements in late August that the Israel-Egypt peace treaty was secure. Lieberman said, "We certainly hope to see Morsi hosting official Israeli representatives soon; we want to see him giving interviews to Israeli media; we want to see him in Jerusalem as President (Shimon) Peres' guest."{{cite web| url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4274149,00.html|title=Lieberman invites Morsi to visit Israel| publisher=Yedioth Ahronot|date=28 August 2012|accessdate=28 August 2012|author=Fyler, Boaz; Magnezi, Aviel}} ===Statements about Palestinians=== Following a series of attacks on Israelis perpetrated by Palestinian militants during a three-day period in March 2002, Lieberman proposed issuing an ultimatum to the [[Palestinian National Authority]] to halt all militant activity or face wide-ranging attacks. He said, "if it were up to me I would notify the Palestinian Authority that tomorrow at ten in the morning we would bomb all their places of business in [[Ramallah]], for example."[http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-1727248,00.html Right: Open War, Left: to Leave the Occupied Territories]. By Smadar Shmueli. [[YNET]]. Published 4 March 2009. This led [[Foreign Affairs Minister of Israel|Foreign Minister]] [[Shimon Peres]] to respond that excessive military measures could lead to accusations of war crimes[https://www.thefirstpost.co.uk/46454,features,avigdor-lieberman-israels-new-hard-man,2?lost=1 Israel's Rising Star]. By Philip Jacobson. ''[[The First Post]]''. Published 5 February 2009. and that the Israeli administration must not "escalate the situation".[http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/we-risk-charges--of-war-crimes-peres-tells-cabinet-653179.html We risk charges of war crimes, Peres tells Cabinet]. By Paul Peachey. ''[[The Independent]]''. Published 7 March 2002. In July 2003, reacting to a commitment made by [[Ariel Sharon]] to the US, where amnesty could be given to approximately 350 Palestinian prisoners including members of [[Hamas]] and [[Islamic Jihad Movement in Palestine|Islamic Jihad]], Lieberman rejected a chance to participate in the related committee and said "It would be better to drown these prisoners in the [[Dead Sea]] if possible, since that's the lowest point in the world,"McGreal, Chris. [http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2003/jul/25/israel Palestinian PM's leadership at stake when he pleads with [[George W. Bush|Bush]] to help free detainees.] ''[[The Guardian]]'', 25 July 2003.Abu Toameh, Khaled. (2003, 21 July.) [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-75596261.html PA prepares own dossier on 'incitement'.]Chazan, Guy. [http://online.wsj.com/article/SB105952212075781800.html?mod=googlewsj Hawkish Palestinian TV Starts to Incubate Doves.] [[Wall Street Journal]] Lieberman continued, according to [[Galei Tzahal]] ('Israel Army Radio'), stating his willingness, as Minister of Transport, to supply buses to take the prisoners there.[http://news.walla.co.il/?w=//409686 'Lieberman offered to drown the Palestinian prisoners at sea'] by [[Walla!]], 6 July 2003
- On Galei Tzahal it was reported that Lieberman said at the cabinet meeting that as Minister of Transport he's willing to provide buses to take them at sea and drown them there.
{{lang-he|???? ??"? ???? ??????? ??? ?????? ?????? ???? ??????? ??? ???? ???? ????????? ??????? ????? ???? ??? ??????? ???? ??.}} Lieberman's suggestion also led to confrontation between Lieberman and Arab-Israeli MKs [[Ahmed Tibi]] ([[Hadash]]-[[Ta'al]]), [[Jamal Zahalka]] ([[Balad (political party)|Balad]]), [[Taleb el-Sana]], Abdelmalek Dahamsha ([[United Arab List]]) as well as opposition leader [[Shimon Peres]].[http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/pages/ShArt.jhtml?itemNo=315541 Lieberman blasted for suggesting drowning Palestinian prisoners] [[Haaretz|Ha'aretz]], 8 July 2006. In January 2009, during the [[Gaza War]], Lieberman argued that Israel "must continue to fight Hamas just like the United States did with the [[Japan]]ese in [[World War II]]. Then, too, the [[Occupied Japan|occupation of the country]] was unnecessary."[http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1231774444907&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull Lieberman: Do to Hamas what the US did to Japan] This threat was been interpreted by some media commentators, including Turkish Prime Minister [[Recep Tayyip Erdogan]], as an allusion to [[Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki|Hiroshima and Nagasaki]] and as advocacy for a [[nuclear warfare|nuclear strike]] on Gaza.{{cite news |title=Israeli politician calls for nuclear strike on Gaza |publisher=[[Ma'an News]] |date=13 January 2009 |url=http://www.maannews.net/en/index.php?opr=ShowDetails&ID=34924}}{{cite news |title=Avigdor Lieberman, Israel's shame |first=Neve |last=Gordon |work=The Guardian |location=London |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2009/mar/25/avigdor-lieberman-binyamin-netanyahu-israel |date=25 March 2009 }}{{cite news |url=http://andrewsullivan.theatlantic.com/the_daily_dish/2009/03/netanyahus-love.html |title=Netanyahu's Love Bombs To America |first=Andrew |last=Sullivan |work=[[The Atlantic]] |date=17 March 2009}}{{cite news|author=Robert Tait in Istanbul |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/oct/26/turkey-iran1 |title='Iran is our friend,' says Turkish PM Recep Tayyip Erdogan |work=The Guardian |location=London |date= 26 October 2009|accessdate=25 April 2010 }} ===Conflict with Mossad=== In 2011, Lieberman became the first Foreign Minister to sever ties with the [[Mossad]].Ravid, Barak. [http://www.haaretz.com/news/national/lieberman-mossad-chief-meet-in-bid-to-end-row-1.396654?localLinksEnabled=false "Lieberman, Mossad chief meet in bid to end row."] ''Haaretz Newspaper'', 20 November 2011. ===Putin=== Lieberman's pro-Russian stance and open admiration of [[Vladimir Putin]] have also drawn criticism from fellow Israelis.{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/newsdesk/2012/10/netanyahus-dark-choice.html|title=Netanyahu’s Dark Choice}} ==Investigations and allegations== ===Corruption=== Some of Lieberman's connections with local and foreign businessmen are currently under police investigation. Lieberman allegedly received millions of shekels from various entrepreneurs while serving as member of Knesset; under Israeli law, MKs are not allowed to receive any payment beyond their salary. One claim is that [[Michael Cherney]] paid a company called Path to the East large amounts of money between the years 1999 and 2006, and that these sums were then allegedly passed on to Lieberman as a bribe. Other allegations concern a company called M.L.1, founded by Lieberman's daughter Michal when she was 21.{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/846337.html |title=Who's the boss? |work=Haaretz |location=Israel |accessdate=25 April 2010}} These allegations concern money transferred to M.L.1 from unknown sources outside Israel; the money was later allegedly used for paying salaries to Avigdor and Michal Lieberman.[[Uri Blau]]. [http://www.haaretz.co.il/hasite/pages/ShArt.jhtml?itemNo=1068888 The Small Fund and the Screenplay Written by Israel Beitenu Leader Avigdor Lieberman] [[Haaretz]], 6 March 2009 (in Hebrew) Lieberman is also under investigation for receiving a bribe from Austrian-Jewish businessman [[Martin Schlaff]].Hillel Fendel.[http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/95989 "Police Say There´s Evidence Linking Sharon to $3 Million Bribe"] Arutz Sheva, 3 January 2006 Lieberman denies all allegations of wrongdoing in these cases, and claims that the police are conspiring against him. In particular, he has pointed to the proximity of his investigation to the [[2009 Israeli election]]s and said that such investigations are "part of my routine before every parliamentary election." Allegations of bias on the part of the police have also been reported in [[Arutz Sheva]], a right-wing Israeli news outlet, which reported that the investigation, which had been "ongoing for years, suddenly became active again once [Lieberman] left the government" in January 2008.Ezra HaLevi. [http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/125032 Exposé Links Olmert, Lieberman and Sharon to Jericho Casino] Arutz Sheva, 24 January 2008 On 2 April 2009, Lieberman was questioned by police on suspicion of corruption for at least seven hours at the national squad headquarters in central Israel. It was part of an ongoing investigation examining his business dealings. Lieberman denied all allegations. He claimed the investigation has been dragged out, and had filed a petition to the court requesting a speedy process.{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2009/04/200942145820429387.html|title=Israeli FM questioned over graft|publisher=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=2 April 2009}} ====Indictment==== On 24 May 2010 the [[Israeli Police]] recommended Lieberman's indictment for Breach of Trust, regarding the suspected receipt of classified information concerning ongoing criminal investigations into his activities. Former ambassador to [[Belarus]], [[Ze'ev Ben Aryeh]] was also recommended for indictment.{{cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/national/israel-police-indict-avigdor-lieberman-for-breach-of-trust-1.291999|title=Israeli FM recommended for indictment|work=Haaretz|date=24 May 2010}} On 13 April 2011, the State Prosecutor's Office announced that it had decided to charge Lieberman with [[fraud]], [[money laundering]], [[English trusts law|breach of trust]] and [[witness tampering]].{{cite news|last=Glickman|first=Aviad|title=Lieberman to face criminal indictment|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4055903,00.html|accessdate=14 April 2011|newspaper=Ynetnews|date=13 April 2011}} The hearing has been set for 17–18 January 2012.Bar-Zohar, Ophir. [http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/lieberman-indictment-hearing-set-for-january-17-1.405161?localLinksEnabled=false "Lieberman indictment hearing set for January 17."] ''Haaretz Newspaper'', 3 January 2012. On 13 December 2012, a [[CNN]] breaking news blog post stated that the Israeli Justice Ministry had decided to only charge him with [[breach of trust]] and [[fraud]], and not the more serious [[witness tampering]] and [[money laundering]] corruption charges.http://news.blogs.cnn.com/?hpt=hp_t3 on 14 December 2012, Liberman announced that he removing his immunity and resigned as foreign minister.[http://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/15/world/middleeast/avigdor-lieberman-israeli-foreign-minister-resigns.html?_r=0 Hard-Line Israeli Foreign Minister Resigns] ===Conviction for assault=== On 24 September 2001, Lieberman acknowledged in the Jerusalem District Court that he attacked a twelve-year-old youth from [[Tekoa, Gush Etzion|Tekoa]], who had hit his son. The incident occurred in December 1999 in the [[Nokdim]] settlement. His son told him that three boys hit him. Lieberman located one of the boys in a trailer and hit him in the face. After the boy fell and was injured, Lieberman grabbed him by the shirt-collar and arm, took him back to his home in Tekoa and threatened that he would attack him again if he returned to Nokdim.{{cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/news/home.aspx?fid=2&did=523942 |title=?????? ????? ???? ????? ?????? ????? ?????? ???? ??????? – ????? |publisher=Globes.co.il |date=24 September 2001 |accessdate=25 April 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://info1.court.gov.il/Prod01/ManamHTML.nsf/7990A9BFEC001F5242256AD20060A81B/$FILE/D925DA0750B1314242256AD200242994.html?OpenElement |title=Court Record (Hebrew) |publisher=Info1.court.gov.il |date=17 December 1999 |accessdate=25 April 2010}} He was charged with assaulting and threatening him. Lieberman was convicted based on his own confession in the context of a [[plea bargain]]. His attorney asked the judges, in the context of the arrangement, to restrict his punishment to a [[fine (penalty)|fine]] amid the defendant’s promise that he will not commit such an act in the future. The judge ultimately ruled that Lieberman must pay the child a compensation of 10,000 [[Israeli new shekel|NIS]], and an additional fine of 7,500 NIS. ===Allegations of Anti-Arabism=== Many commentators, including [[Arab Israeli]] groups, have accused Lieberman of [[Anti-Arabism]]. Christoph Schult in ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' noted that Lieberman is reputed to be a "virulent racist".{{cite news |title=Israel's Pragmatic Thug|first=Christoph|last=Schult|work=[[Der Spiegel]]|date=25 March 2009 |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,615392,00.html}} [[M.J. Rosenberg]] in the ''[[LA Times]]'' characterized Lieberman's election campaign as "frankly anti-Arab".{{cite news|title=The rise of Avigdor Lieberman|first=M.J.|last=Rosenberg |work=Los Angeles Times|date=11 February 2009 |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/printedition/opinion/la-oe-rosenberg11-2009feb11,0,5037251.story}} Daphna Baram in ''[[The Guardian]]'' called him an "arch racist".{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2009/mar/26/israel-labour-binyamin-netanyahu-ehud-barak|first=Daphna |last=Baram|date=26 March 2009|work=The Guardian|location=London|title=The Knesset: many parties, one mind}} [[Richard Cohen (columnist)|Richard Cohen]] in the ''[[Washington Post]]'' noted that while Lieberman a "nationalist" he was also an "anti-Arab demagogue".{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/02/23/AR2009022302291.html|first=Richard|last=Cohen|date=24 February 2009|work=The Washington Post|title=Whose Israel Shall It Be?}} [[Eric Yoffie]], president of the [[Union for Reform Judaism]] called Lieberman's campaign "an outrageous, abominable, hate-filled campaign, brimming with incitement that, if left unchecked, could lead Israel to the gates of hell." {{cite news|url=http://www.forward.com/articles/103178/ |title=Jewish Leaders Largely Silent on Lieberman’s Role In Government But One Prominent U.S. Rabbi Criticizes ‘Hate-Filled Campaign’|work=[[The Forward]]|date=27 February 2009 |first=Nathan |last=Guttman}} [[Martin Peretz]] editor-in-chief of ''[[The New Republic]]'', a passionate Zionist and critic of the peace movement, called Lieberman "neo-fascist ... a certified gangster ... the Israeli equivalent of [[Jörg Haider]]" {{cite news|url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/184765|title=Israel's Biggest Danger|first=Fareed |last=Zakaria|date=14 February 2009|work=Newsweek}} During the 2009 campaign, [[Meretz]] released an internal memo comparing Lieberman to "[[Jean-Marie Le Pen]] in France, [[Jörg Haider|Haider]] in Austria, and [[Vladimir Zhirinovsky|Zhirinovsky]] in Russia" {{cite news|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3662172,00.html |title=Meretz memo: Compare Lieberman to Jorg Haider|first=Eli|last=Senyor|publisher=[[YNet news]]|date=26 January 2009}} Party officials denied the charges, saying that they were falsely stigmatized.Gideon Alon, [http://news.haaretz.co.il/hasen/pages/ShArtStEngPE.jhtml?itemNo=830503&contrassID=2&subContrassID=5&title=%27Not%20racist,%20stigmatized%20%27&dyn_server=172.20.5.5 Not racist, stigmatized],
